conclusion: The loop is an equilateral triangle CDE with side length a. A uniform magnetic field B exists to the right of the dotted line MN, directed perpendicular to the plane of the loop. The loop moves to the right with a constant speed v, and side CD remains perpendicular to MN. We need to find the maximum induced EMF from the moment point D reaches the boundary MN until point C fully enters the magnetic field.

Place the dotted line MN along the y-axis (x = 0), with the magnetic field in the region x > 0. The loop is moving to the right, so its velocity is v i. Since CD is perpendicular to MN, let’s align CD parallel to the y-axis. At the initial moment when D reaches MN, position D at (0, 0). Side CD has length a, so point C is at (0, a). Since CDE is an equilateral triangle, the coordinates of E can be found: The base CD lies along the y-axis from (0, 0) to (0, a). The height of an equilateral triangle with side a is h = sqrt(3)/2 a. The x-coordinate of E (the apex) is at x = -sqrt(3)/2 a, and its y-coordinate is the midpoint of CD, so y = a/2. Thus, E is at (-sqrt(3)/2 a, a/2).
At time t = 0, D is at (0, 0). As the loop moves with speed v, at time t: D moves to (vt, 0), C moves to (vt, a), E moves to (vt - sqrt(3)/2 a, a/2).

At t = 0, point D is on the boundary x = 0. Point C enters the magnetic field when its x-coordinate equals 0: C’s x-coordinate is vt. C crosses x = 0 at t = 0, but we interpret “until C enters” as the moment C is fully in the field, considering the motion. The key interval is from when D enters (t = 0) until E (the leftmost point) crosses x = 0, because the flux changes only while part of the loop is entering the field. E’s x-coordinate is vt - sqrt(3)/2 a. E crosses x = 0 when: vt - sqrt(3)/2 a = 0 implies vt = sqrt(3)/2 a implies t = sqrt(3) a/2 v. So, we consider t from 0 to sqrt(3) a/2 v, the time when the entire loop is in the magnetic field, and flux stops changing.

The induced EMF is given by Faraday’s Law: E = -dPhi/dt, where Phi = B * A is the magnetic flux, and A is the area of the loop inside the magnetic field. The magnetic field B is uniform in x > 0. We need to calculate the area of the loop to the right of x = 0 as a function of time.

At time t, the boundary x = 0 intersects the loop, and we need the area of the portion where x > 0. At t = 0, only points C and D are at x = 0, and E is at x = -sqrt(3)/2 a, so the area inside is 0. At t = sqrt(3) a/2 v, E reaches x = 0, and the entire loop is in the field. For 0 < t < sqrt(3) a/2 v, the line x = 0 intersects the loop at two sides: DE and CE.
